hawaiian_text: A make ‘o Puali‘i, ho‘i akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī, noho ihola lāua, ‘a‘ohe ‘ai o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka ‘ai. I ia wā, e noho ana ‘o  ‘Ama‘u he ali‘i no O‘ahu nei, ma Waikīkī kahi i noho ai, hele maila kekahi kanaka no Honouliuli  mai ā hiki ma Waikīkī, e noho ana ke ali‘i. ‘Ōlelo  akula ia: “E ke alii ē\! He ‘oi kahi keiki ‘u‘uku ikaika  loa, ua make kona makua kāne a ua kiola ‘ia kona  po‘o i kai loa, he wahi lō‘ihi loa, ‘elima mile ka  lō‘ihi. A lohe o ‘Ama‘u, aia kona ikaika a make au iā  ia, akā, i ‘ole au e make iā ia ‘a‘ohe ona ikaika. Iā ia  e ‘ōlelo ana ma Waikīkī, ua lohe nō ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo nona.
llama4-scout-fireworks_translation: When Puali'i died, Nāmakaokapāo'o went back to his mother, Pōka'ī, and they lived together, but Nāmakaokapāo'o didn't eat. At that time, 'Ama'u, a chief from O'ahu, was living in Waikīkī. A man from Honouliuli arrived at Waikīkī where the chief was living. He said: "O chief! There is a small, incredibly strong boy whose father has died, and his head was thrown into the deep sea, a very long distance, five miles long. If I hear that he is strong and I have to fight him, I will die. But if I don't have to fight him, then I won't die." When he was talking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o heard these words about him.
llama4-scout-fireworks_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
When Puali'i died, Nāmakaokapāo'o went back to his mother, Pōka'ī, and they lived together, but Nāmakaokapāo'o didn't eat. At that time, 'Ama'u, a chief from O'ahu, was living in Waikīkī. A man from Honouliuli arrived at Waikīkī where the chief was living. He said: "O chief! There is a small, incredibly strong boy whose father has died, and his head was thrown into the deep sea, a very long distance, five miles long. If I hear that he is strong and I have to fight him, I will die. But if I don't have to fight him, then I won't die." When he was talking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o heard these words about him.
</translation>

<commentary>
• This paragraph marks a turning point in the narrative, where Nāmakaokapāo'o's life with his mother, Pōka'ī, takes a new direction with the introduction of 'Ama'u, a chief from O'ahu, and a man from Honouliuli who brings news of Nāmakaokapāo'o's reputation.

– The name 'A-ma'u- (m) can be broken down into 'A- (prefix) and ma'u (m), with 'ma'u possibly derived from the Hawaiian word for "cloud" or "mist." This could signify 'Ama'u's connection to the spiritual or celestial realm.

– The arrival of the man from Honouliuli serves as a catalyst for the events that will unfold, as he brings news of Nāmakaokapāo'o's strength and the circumstances of his father's death.

• The 'Ai Kapu era's cultural practices and values are still evident in this passage, particularly in the emphasis on strength, bravery, and the consequences of conflict.

– The mention of Nāmakaokapāo'o's father being killed and his head thrown into the sea may be a reference to the practice of 'Ai Kapu, where human sacrifice was sometimes used as a substitute for fish, like the ulua.

• The narrative also alludes to the theme of reputation and how it can precede an individual, influencing the actions and decisions of others.

– Nāmakaokapāo'o's strength and reputation are highlighted, setting the stage for future conflicts and challenges.

• The use of specific locations like Waikīkī and Honouliuli adds depth to the narrative, grounding the story in actual Hawaiian geography.

– Waikīkī, in particular, holds cultural significance as a site of royal residence and spiritual importance.

• The passage showcases the complexities of Hawaiian cultural tradition, where strength, bravery, and reputation were highly valued, but also where the consequences of conflict and violence were ever-present.

– The character of 'Ama'u, as a chief from O'ahu, represents the hierarchical structure of Hawaiian society during the 'Ai Kapu era, with chiefs holding positions of power and authority.
reference_translation: When Puali‘i died, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back  to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and the two lived together,  but Nāmakaokapāo‘o had nothing to eat. At that  time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu in Waikīkī,  where he lived. A man of Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was found. The man said,  “Chief, there is a little boy who is amazingly strong.  He killed his father and threw his head in the  ocean a really long distance away, five miles off.”  When ‘Ama‘u heard this, he said, “We’ll see how  strong he is if he kills me. But if he doesn’t kill me,  he isn’t strong at all.” When he said this in Waikīkī,  Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard what he was saying about  him.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14**• From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of  Christianity’s defeat over the ‘Ai Kapu, with   Nāmakaokapāo‘o representing progressive   Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his  mother, Pōka‘ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians’ futile attempts to hold onto ‘Ai Kapu culture.
